Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Dual Burden Life History Tradeoffs in the Exploration of Childhood Gut Immune Function and Overnutrition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Frequent intestinal infections due to poor water quality and inadequate sanitation during childhood often result in chronic malnutrition and linear growth restrictions. Many developing countries, however, are now undergoing diet and disease transitions, with a shift from frequent malnutrition and infectious disease to increasing overnutrition, with calorically-dense, high-fat, low-fiber diets, and higher rates of overweight and obesity. The impact of this dual burden of infection and overnutrition on childhood intestinal health and immune function remains unknown. Doctoral student Kelly Houck (University of North Carolina), with the guidance of Dr. Amanda Thompson, draws on the emerging field of study focusing on gut microbiota, the beneficial bacterial colonies responsible for intestinal barrier function, digestion of dietary fiber and immune health (inflammatory regulation), to examine the impact of pathogenic and dietary factors on the relationship between childhood gut immune health, growth and obesity.

The Gal√°pagos Islands of Ecuador are an important setting for this research as children experience both high infection rates due to the lack of clean water and overnutrition, likely due to the reliance on processed foods shipped from the mainland. Researchers will collect detailed data on the children's diet, illness history, and household characteristics, and will measure growth and adiposity, household water quality, and gut immune function using blood spot and fecal analyses. This project tests the hypothesis that in dual burden environments, concurrent pathogenic exposures and overnutrition contribute to gut immune dysregulation, creating a new synergism between overnutrition and infection that may be driving the paradoxical pattern of childhood stunting and obesity seen in such populations.

In developing countries where economic development and urbanization are rapidly transforming human health, the need to understand how these changes are affecting childhood immune function and growth is urgent to prevent the high rates of infection, stunting and obesity. The proposed project offers training to university students and a community health worker in Ecuador. The results will provide original insights into the impacts of gut immune activation on childhood growth and obesity and identify important targets for public health education and interventions relevant to the Galapagos, Ecuador, and other non-industrialized populations undergoing transition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rise of childhood obesity is a global health epidemic, mainly caused by the adoption of high-fat, low-fiber diets, rich in sugar, carbohydrates and other processed foods. In high-income countries, obesity is related to inflammation and immune dysfunction that results in metabolic disturbances and heart disease in adulthood. In many low- and middle- income countries, populations face a double burden for inflammation and immune dysfunction due to high rates of infections due to poor water quality and inadequate sanitation and increasing levels of obesity. Children of the Galapagos Island of Ecuador are unfortunately experiencing this dual burden of infectious disease coupled with obesity. The effects on their immune function and intestinal health remain largely unknown. The objectives of this research are: 1) to investigate the impact of high pathogenic exposures and obesity on childhood immune function; and 2) to determine the effects of pathogenic- and obesity-induced immune dysfunction on childhood growth in Galapagos, Ecuador. This research applies developmental and evolutionary frameworks used in biological anthropology to better understand how early life nutritional and disease environments influence human immune function, and to test whether immune activation leads to lower child growth even with adequate energy availability.

Fieldwork was conducted between June 2013 and August 2014 on San Cristobal Island to collect environmental, health and growth data on 164 children ages two to ten years old. Mothers were interviewed about the child’s diet, disease history, demographics and birth information, along with household socioeconomic information and sanitation practices concerning water use. Biological samples were collected from each child and analyzed for immune function biomarkers. Children were weighed and height was measured during the first interview and after six months to determine growth and weight gains. Household tap water samples were collected and analyzed for bacterial contamination.

Statistical analyses revealed that similar to other studies in the US and high-income countries, obesity was highly associated with increased levels of inflammation. However, daily pathogenic exposure due to poor water quality was significantly, independently associated with lower levels inflammation. This research suggests that even in an environment of overnutrition that contributes to higher inflammation, childhood pathogenic exposures that do not result in illness or diarrhea may help to regulate the human immune system. The proper development of inflammatory networks is vital to quickly respond to pathogens and clear infections, without inducing immune dysregulation.

During childhood, the body’s energetic resources must be balanced between the requirements for growth and proper immune function. In population with high rates of infections and limited food reserves, energy resources are diverted from growth to the immune system, resulting in growth deficits in children. The second objective of this research is to determine the costs of both pathogenic- and dietary-induced immune activation on growth and the impact of excess fat stores. Statistical models demonstrate that among children with high levels of immune activation, excess fat stores provided a protective effect and buffer against poor growth. These results are significant, demonstrating that the changing nutritional and disease environments seen in developing countries are associated with rising rates of inflammation and immune dysfunction, with potential long-term consequences for the development of disease.
